    Team News

    Barcelona
    Real Madrid
    • Jordi Alba and Dani Alves return from suspension at a key point for the Blaugrana, with both full-backs set to start at Camp Nou.
    • In the absence of Sergio Busquets, Javier Mascherano will continue in defensive midfield, with Jeremy Mathieu pushed into centre-back as a result.
    • Ivan Rakitic should retain his place in central midfield after a well-taken goal in midweek in the Champions League against Manchester City.
    • Neymar should start on the left-hand side after returning to full training on Friday, with Luis Enrique boasting some intimidating offensive options.
    • James Rodriguez is the only real injury concern for the visitors, with Sami Khedira returning to full training during the last week.
    • Marcelo is expected to start at left-back, despite Carlo Ancelotti sometimes preferring the defensive qualities of Fabio Coentrao in big matches.
    • Luka Modric will continue his comeback from injury with a start in central midfield, alongside both Toni Kroos and Isco.
    • Gareth Bale will take some confidence into this game after netting twice against Levante, lighting up what has been a rather drab month for the Welshman.
    %>

    Prediction

    • Barcelona have lost merely one of their last 18 competitive matches, not drawing once during the same period, with Enrique's men in absolutely formidable form heading into this Clasico.
    • The two sides even had contrasting fortunes in the Champions League during the week, with Los Blancos defeated 4-3 by Schalke on home soil, while the Blaugrana battled to a 1-0 win over Man City.
    • Not only that, but Ancelotti's men have been stuttering in terms of form of late, recording merely two wins in their last five competitive matches. Defeats to Schalke and Athletic Club and a draw against Villarreal has led to some unrest among the visitors' supporters.
    • With just one point separating the two rivals at the top of La Liga, the stakes have rarely been higher in domestic action, with a win for Real Madrid presumably the end of what has turned into a 'mini crisis' for the current Champions League holders.
    • Lionel Messi looked in formidable form against the Citizens, but failed to score, with the Argentina international racking up six goals in his last three La Liga appearances. Cristiano Ronaldo, meanwhile, has netted only once in the same period of games.

    • [ - ] SteveHyland - member since 03-Nov-12

      @two_six- Diving and general cheating is endemic in La Liga not just Ronaldo. Everybody who plays in that league will become infected sooner or later. It's the principle reason people don't watch this league as much as the Prem. "El Clasico" only gets 70% of the viewers as the EPL game between the 2 teams fighting for the title does even though many (including myself) consider the quality of football better. Why? Because people outside of Spain don't like to see their team win as a result of cheating. In Spain, it's "clever", "tactical", "part of the game" but outside of it (well, with the exception of some other continental leagues), it's seen as immoral. You've got no chance actually explaining this to the Spanish though. All they do is bring up "quality of football" clichés as though firstly, people that criticise cheating are somehow equating it to a lack of quality of football (as absurd as that sounds) and secondly that cheating is nullified by the quality of play.
